transportAdvice: Big Sur has no public transit system, and the rugged coastline makes walking between attractions impractical; a personal vehicle or rental car is essentially required to explore the area. Taxis and ride-share options are extremely limited, so visitors should plan all transportation independently before arriving.

weather.description: Cool and wet with frequent rain and coastal fog, but dramatic stormy scenery can be rewarding for hardy visitors.
One of the rainiest months, with lush green hillsides emerging but road closures possible due to slides.
Rain begins to ease and wildflowers start to appear, making for beautiful if occasionally wet hiking conditions.
Mild and increasingly pleasant with blooming wildflowers and clearer skies between lingering coastal fog banks.
Comfortable temperatures and low rainfall make this an excellent month to visit, though morning fog is common.
Warm and mostly dry but coastal fog often rolls in during mornings, burning off by midday.
Peak summer brings warm, dry days with stunning visibility on clear afternoons and busy trails and viewpoints.
The warmest and driest month of the year, ideal for hiking and coastal exploration with long daylight hours.
Excellent conditions continue into early fall with warm temperatures, minimal fog, and fewer crowds than summer.
Mild and mostly dry with golden hillsides and quieter roads, making it one of the most scenic months to visit.
Cooler temperatures and returning rains bring lush greenery but also the risk of mudslides and road closures.
Winter sets in with frequent rain and cool temperatures; dramatic coastal views reward visitors willing to brave the weather.
